title: How to Clean a Furnace Filter

steps.title: Turn off the furnace.
steps.content: Turn off the furnace. Never remove a furnace filter while the furnace is running. Make sure to switch the furnace off before you begin.There is usually a handle somewhere near the furnace that can be switched off. [1] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source If you're unsure how to turn off your furnace, contact your landlord or the manufacturer.

steps.title: Locate the filter.
steps.content: Locate the filter. Inside the furnace, you should see a filter. Usually, the filter is either just inside the furnace or just inside the air vent. The filter should have an arrow on it indicating airflow direction. [2] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source

steps.title: Mark the direction of air flow.
steps.content: Mark the direction of air flow. Before you remove the filter, take a sharpie. Draw an arrow pointing in the direction of airflow somewhere on or near the furnace. This way, you will reinsert the filter in the right direction. [3] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source

steps.title: Remove the filter.
steps.content: Remove the filter. Once you've located the filter, you can remove it. You should not need any special tools. Simply grab the filter with your fingers and slide it out of place. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Make sure the filter is reusable.
steps.content: Make sure the filter is reusable. If your filter has a plastic frame, it's a reusable model. You can clean it out and place it back in your furnace. [5] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source Disposable filters tend to have cardboard frames. For disposable filters, discard the old filters. You will have to get the same type of filter at a hardware store to replace the old one. [6] X Research source Make sure to note the type and size of filter if yours is not reusable. You will need to purchase the same type/size to replace it.

steps.title: Rinse away the dust with water.
steps.content: Rinse away the dust with water. Filter cleaning is actually very simple. No special cleaners are required. You simply rinse your filter under running water water to remove any dirt, dust, or debris caught in the filter. When necessary, turn the filter around to get all the sides clean. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Let the filter dry completely.
steps.content: Let the filter dry completely. Set the filter somewhere to dry once you've cleaned it. It's best to let the filter air dry. Drying times will vary depending on the temperature of your home, but make sure the filter is completely dry before reinserting it in the furnace. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Put the filter back in place.
steps.content: Put the filter back in place. Again, no special equipment is required to reinsert the filter. You simply need to slide it back in place. [9] X Research source Make sure to pay attention to the arrow you drew. Place the filter in the right direction of airflow.

steps.title: Figure out how often your furnace filter needs cleaning or replacing.
steps.content: Figure out how often your furnace filter needs cleaning or replacing. Different types of furnace filters should be cleaned more or less often. Check your filter's label to see what type it is and clean it accordingly. [10] X Research source Electrostatic filters need to be cleaned every three months. Electronic filters should be cleaned weekly. Mechanical filters are not reusable and should be replaced once a month.

steps.title: Keep records of when you cleaned your filter.
steps.content: Keep records of when you cleaned your filter. Each time you clean your filter, make a note of it. Write it down on a physical calendar or one in your home. Make a note of when the filter needs to be changed next. This will help you stay proactive about cleaning your furnace filter. [11] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source

steps.title: Replace your filter regularly.
steps.content: Replace your filter regularly. Even reusable filters have a shelf life. Check your filter's label or read your furnace's instructions manual. This will tell you how long your filter will last. Electromagnetic filters, however, do not need replacing unless they are severely damaged. [12] X Research source
